PM

Let me get some ECB grey

PM

Today’s ECB meeting was more dovish than we anticipated, prompting us to put more ECB easing into our forecast. Our colleagues have viewed this as a very close call for a while and now expect a combination of three measures at the next meeting in December: a €10 billion increase in the monthly pace of QE to €70 billion per month; a three-month extension of the purchases to December 2016, raising the total amount purchased under the program by €300 billion (3% of GDP); and, finally, a 10bp cut of the deposit rate to -0.30%. Greg Fuzesi thinks this set of measures would be an appropriate response to the projected undershooting of inflation in 2017 and assessments of QE effectiveness in other countries. It also would strike a balance between delivering stimulus quickly and keeping options open for the future. By acting, the ECB would enhance the credibility of its easing bias going forward.

11:15 am
PM

That's JPM

PM

With the ECB appearing to signal action, it will be interesting to see what the BoJ does next week. The data flow from Japan has improved of late, though our economists still think the economy contracted slightly last quarter. One wild card is the Japanese government’s seeming aversion to further FX depreciation. Our call remains that the BoJ will announce more easing.

PM

And some BNY mellon

11:16 am
PM

It was widely believed that Mario Draghi would adopt an explicitly dovish stance following the ECB Council meeting yesterday and the President did not disappoint: whilst evidently keen to portray as positive an assessment as possible, Mr Draghi nonetheless divulged that additional QE would be considered in December, that the purchase program would continue beyond 2016 'if needed' and that there had even been a discussion about cutting the deposit rate at yesterday's meeting. And the result? EUR/USD sank like a stone, dropping a big figure before Mr Draghi had even concluded proceedings. So, if we are to take Mr Draghi at his word (and assume that a little 'pre-committing' has been made), then the question becomes which instrument (or instruments) the ECB will favour adjusting? Well, Mr Draghi assured that the Council is "open to a whole menu of instruments", but then, not all are necessarily up to the job.

PM

We suspect that a further round of TLTRO can be safely precluded: the take up of the last tranche in September was a paltry EUR 15.5 Bn and just one quarter of the amount expected. Besides, the debate rages on as to the efficacy of the program and what it has achieved save for providing a welcome boost to the Euro-zone's sovereign debt market - although to be fair, the same might be said of QE itself. Yet one unequivocally positive side-effect of QE was that it helped to engineer a weaker EUR and by doing so, it presented the Euro-zone with an export flavoured tonic after four years of depression. And let's be quite clear, this was the principle, albeit tacit goal of the policies introduced from last summer onwards. Of course, Mr Draghi was keen to dispel talk that the EUR is a policy target, but then, the combination of counter-cyclical fiscal policy and a flawed fiscal compact demanded the lifeline of a trade boost - a fact that explains Ireland's relative outperformance through much of the crisis. And not only did Mr Draghi concede that a stronger EUR constitutes a risk to growth yesterday, but the ECB's designs on a competitive euro have been fairly transparent throughout: on October 13th last year for example, Ewald Nowotny innocently explained to the WSJ that "the different tendencies in interest rate policies (between the Eurozone, the US and the UK) [means] there is a great likelihood that this leads to a further depreciation of the EUR."

PM

There is certainly ample scope for the ECB to crank up QE: over the summer, VP Vitor Constancio observed that "The total amount that we have purchased represents 5.3% of GDP of the Euro-zone, whereas what the Fed has done represents almost 25% of US GDP ... So we are very far from what the major central banks have done." However, the ECB cannot simply raise its asset purchases in December (as Mr Draghi has alluded to) with impunity. Objections from Weidmann and Lautenschläger are a given of course, but a number of officials globally have begun to voice concerns about the collateral damage wreaked by protracted monetary stimulus. Aside from the usual suspects - Kiuchi, Mester, George, Forbes and so on - Luxembourg's Finance Minister Pierre Gramegna said at the recent G20 in Ankara that "We cannot live all the time on easy money"; and Ewald Nowotny was heard to say that "It's clear ... that there are limits to the effectiveness of monetary policy ... we are looking very closely at the possibility of asset bubbles being created in the [Euro-zone's] property market". Indeed, on this latter point, it might be argued that whilst QE has had questionable success in boosting growth and consumer price inflation in the Euro-zone, it has been rather effective in underpinning asset prices: agents Engel & Völkers report that prime property in Germany's major cities h ave just reached new highs.

11:16 am
NC

@theleggie: sadly, the history of directors' buys shows they have little more idea of when a stock is cheap than the rest of us

PM

It is for this reason that we are quite prepared to believe that many of Mr Draghi's colleagues were prepared to cut the deposit rate further at yesterday's meeting. Although expectations obviously played a part, it must be remembered that EUR/USD had fallen by 16% before QE was launched on account of the ECB's decision to charge for holding reserves last summer. The problem with this option of course is that it would take the ECB further into unknown territory to the consternation of the Bank's principal benefactor, Germany; and whilst a deeper deposit cut might further undermine the EUR, it also (ostensibly) imposes new costs on the banking sector, thereby encouraging banks to pay down debt rather than stimulate new credit. Jens Weidmann had a point when he told the Sueddeutsche Zeitung last month that "All the cheap money cannot ignite sustained growth and builds bigger risks over time, for example for financial stability". Indeed, it is for this reason that we believe Mario Draghi is making a more concerted push for governments to help shoulder the burden of underpinning growth.

PM

Sorry there's a lot of this

11:16 am
PM

At Jackson Hole last year, Mr Draghi stated "since 2010 the Euro-zone has suffered from fiscal policy being less available and effective, especially compared with other large advanced economies ... Thus, it would be helpful for the overall stance of policy if fiscal policy could play a greater role alongside monetary policy, and I believe there is scope for this". In laying down a challenge to the Euro-zone's modus operandi on fiscal policy, the statement grabbed the headlines and sparked a debate - so much so in fact that Wolfgang Schäuble felt inclined to intervene: he told Passauer Neue Presse newspaper, "I know Mario Draghi very well, I think he is being over interpreted." Maybe, but Mr Draghi's comments a month later sounded remarkably similar: he told Lithuanian business daily Verslo Zinios "It is now in the hands of governments to act decisively on further structural reforms. Governments should not unravel the progress made in fiscal consolidation, but use any leeway to make fiscal policies more growth-friendly." And at yesterday's post-decision press conference, Mr Draghi observed that "monetary policy should not be the only game in town" - recent history makes it quite clear what Mr Draghi was referring to.

We have written at length on the implications of a Euro-zone current account surplus in a global economy where policy stimuli may be reaching its limits, but for the time being, the point is academic given that a balanced budget is now enshrined in German law. However, the fact that Mario Draghi has once more revealed a desire for fiscal policy to share the burden might tip the argument in favour of ECB policy measures that more directly target the euro than the money supply per se. We shall see, but then of course we must ponder the likely efficacy of a weaker currency in leveraging growth from a weakening global economy.

Advisers to HSBC say the US is one of the few countries with an economy big enough to be able to comfortably welcome a bank of its size. HSBC has $2.6tn of assets, making it almost as big as the entire British economy. Bankers also view US financial regulation as more accommodating of large universal banks.

PM

Ian Gordon of Investec

PM

Although we expect HSBC to post sharply lower Reported PBT in Q3 2015e of $4.7bn (down 28% QoQ), this largely reflects non-recurrence of one-offs (with an impeccably timed $1bn Industrial Bank disposal gain in Q2 2015) and seasonal revenue trends in GB&M. In addition to these factors, we model a reversal of the spike in Q2 2015 equity-related earnings in Hong Kong, and we allow for USD strength vs GBP, Asian and LATAM currencies. Despite all this, the core investment case remains substantially unchanged. BUY.

PM

We continue to see HSBC’s primary issue as a “revenue problem”. For the past seven years, it has simply been unable to find sufficient loan growth opportunities to “replace” its exit from over 80 businesses/markets – most notably the Household disaster in North America. Moreover, “lower for (much) longer” interest rates have compounded the problem for it as a (generally) risk-averse, deposit-heavy bank. Its loans:deposit ratio fell to just 71.4% in Q2 2015, and we still do not expect it to achieve RoE

10% before 2018e.

In Q3 2015e, we forecast u/l revenues of $14.1bn (-8% QoQ/-12% YoY) but with the decline partially offset by u/l costs of $8.5bn (-7% QoQ/-10% YoY). We forecast an impairment charge of just $0.9bn (38bps) giving underlying PBT of $5.3bn (-13% QoQ/-19% YoY). We forecast exceptional items to swing from +$0.5bn in Q2 2015e to -$0.6bn in Q3 2015 (reflecting conduct and restructuring costs), hence reported PBT of $4.7bn (-28% QoQ/+3% YoY).
We detail our forecasts in the charts and tables on pages 2-4. For us, the key issues are that (1) Hong Kong remains dominant – c.46% of Q3 2015e PBT, (2) impairments remain structurally low, (3) revenues continue to decline (in part FX), but (4) capital is adequate and the dividend is covered/sustainable.
For FY 2015e, our PBT of £20.6bn is 5% below Company-compiled consensus.
Trading on 1.0x 2015-17e tNAV with a prospective 2015-17e dividend yield of 6.5-7.0%, we reaffirm our Buy rec but cut our target price to 605p (from 635p).

Helen Haworth from Credit Suisse

11:32 am
PM

Divergence is not yet dead. Draghi's press conference very clearly reminded
markets that it is too early simply to sell rates vol on the assumption that there
will be no more market opportunities in 2015.
The reception of the ECB's press conference reinforces our view that the nearterm
divergence trade will likely come primarily from pricing for additional easing
from the ECB (and BoJ). The explicit mention of a depo rate cut should allow
the market to price for a lower range in EUR yields to the benefit of both fixed
income and equity markets.
The October ECB meeting confirmed our view of a QE extension in December.
But we now believe the ECB can cut the deposit rate by 10bps in December,
too. We also think the risk of further cuts in 2016 should get priced further into
money market curves.
We favor long positions in the front end, either through EUR satellites or through
ER flatteners, while we now expect curves to steepen further out. We continue
to favor EUR 15s30s steepener. We still believe getting long Bund conditionally
is the right trade and recommend buying the RXF6 161/163 Call Spread for
45cts.

PM

Next week's Fed statement is unlikely to provide any material change, in our
view, as neither data nor financial markets point to the Fed adopting a materially
more hawkish tone – or a substantially more dovish one, for that matter. We
view the debt ceiling as a greater source of concern for markets over the
coming week assuming the stalemate grinds on, with pricing of risk likely to spill
over from a select few Treasury securities into risk assets more broadly.
In the US we also discuss financial issuance and risks to swap spreads,
highlighting TLAC-related issuance as a potential source of issuance-related
downside pressure on longer-dated spreads. We consider the Fed's Treasury
reinvestment strategy, suggesting it would be best served to bias reinvestments
toward the short end. We also favor selling 10y Treasuries on the PCAweighted
3s10s30s fly to position for a re-normalization of the spread.
In the UK, we look ahead to the upcoming BoE Inflation Report. We recommend
positioning for a knee-jerk sell-off on the back of a 7-2 vote by entering a
tactical outright short in Dec-17 short sterling.

11:55 am
PM

William Hill has reported Q3 results this morning, with Group revenue -9% yoy
and Group EBITA -39% yoy. Management expect FY operating profit to be at the lower end
of current market consensus range (£291-£312m).

PM

In Online, net revenue was -3% yoy. Sportsbook revenue was -9% yoy, with wagers +2%
and gross win margin -80 bps (due to the less favourable results yoy). UK amounts wagered
were +7%, with Italy +24% (cc) and Spain +13% (cc). Gaming in UK was +15% yoy
(gaming overall +2%). Non core markets (which are a higher profit contribution) were the
main driver of weakness. Currency, market closures and regulatory change doing the
damage (wagers in non core were -14%). Online marketing as a % of net revenue was 19%
(20% in Q314), and we expect this to be questioned on the call.
In UK Retail, net revenue was -8% yoy and operating profit was -31% yoy. OTC amounts
wagered were +2% yoy (+3% lfl) and gross win margin was 16.6% (Q314: 19.7%).
Machines revenue was -2% yoy (-1% lfl), the group noted that the run-rate improved
towards the end of Q3 following roll out new B3 content. Retail operating costs were -4%
yoy, highlighting tight cost control.
William Hill Australia net revenue was -24% yoy (cc), with wagers -18% yoy and gross win
margin was flat at 10.2% (Q314: 10.2%). Operating profit was -89% yoy (lc). Sporting
results impacted William Hill US with gross win -16% yoy, but underlying remains strong
with amounts stake +35% yoy (lc).

PM

They're struggling online

11:56 am
PM

Overall, we expect to downgrade FY15 forecasts by 2% following this morning’s
update (£300m currently). This downgrade is disappointing but expectations were
relatively low coming into these numbers. The main driver of downgrades is a
reduction in our online forecasts to reflect the continued impact from weakness in
non-core markets. There are a number of factors behind this including currency,
market exits, and regulatory blocking. The underlying performance in core online is
more encouraging (UK stakes +7% and gaming +15%), but it will be into 2016
before non-core weakness is no longer an issue. Australia continues to
underperform and significant question marks remain over this business in a
growing market. On a positive note the underlying performance in retail is slightly
better than we forecast. Following the downgrades, the stock will continue to imply
a low valuation. However, any significant share price appreciation may have to wait
until the online business returns to delivering revenue and profit growth.

PM

And Shore

PM

Overall, we see the combination of falling non-core revenues, slightly weaker than expected sports margin (horse racing offsetting good football) and a far weaker than expected performance in Australia leading to a reduction in full year estimates. We downgrade our EBIT estimate by c£10m to £290m (EPS down c1p to £24.5p). Overall, we estimate that this downgrade is split c£5m for non-core and £5m for Australia. For next year, we see a similar downgrade of c£10m to £310m (EPS 25.3p) reflecting the drag from non-core territories although this drag should lessen as the year progresses – although this would imply little progresses given the likely benefit from Euro 2016.

11:57 am
PM

We see today’s update as disappointing. We recently highlighted that the fall in the share price was leaving the group starting to look good value and still trades on c13x next year’s numbers pre the likely fall in the share price. However, getting through the drag from non-core territories is likely key for a re-rating. HOLD.
